title: Do start ups contribute to the economy? - Quora

response.answer_text: Startup is a fashionable word. The larger frame is “ Entrepreneurship” , which is a very important engine for growth of any economy. Entrepreneurship need not necessarily be through a startup route ( of course startup route makes it easy for small entrepreneurs ). Forty years back , economies were dependent more on Natural resources than human resources. Then Technology has changed the equation , countries with better intellectual capital who can develop better and productive technologies or better skill base started prospering. While technology development was mostly dominated by big corporate giants , with the advent of internet , Individuals /small groups could find methods of increasing Productivity , value to Consumers/Enterprises without much infrastructure, investment and within a short time. Startups do create some economic activity , provide some jobs . But if the success rate of startups is say , one in ten . This will lead to disruptions in terms of loss of some capital and jobs . While people can always get jobs again , it would be harsh on some people . The case of success stories also ends up many times by acquisitions and in turn some churning , consolidation and loss of jobs. While it is good , the general feeling is that start -up route is the fastest route to prosperity . While everybody has a right to attain this this prosperity , it should not become a cess pool into which best talent gets sucked . It should not happen that we will miss genuine Entrepreneurship which can bring more value to the world at large

All businesses contribute to the economic growth of a county. The significance of a startup's contribution in its true essence is quite debatable though. Like all businesses, startups generate employment, create economic opportunities for partners/ ancillary businesses and some drive influx of foreign currency into domestic markets. While all this is true, the success of a startup in today's economy is measured in the amount of dollars that it raises through a series of funding rounds. All this circus means that the chances of a startup succeeding is in small fractions…. And the government policies in India make it make it all the more interesting. Well, that brings us to the sustainability of a startup. We have seen a major rise in the fall of funded startups over the years. I reckon our top B schools set people to raise money, but as results have shown us, true entrepreneurship is being able to create a self sustaining business. This is where things start going South owing to low or no experience in running a business of our young Entrepreneurs, who definitely start with a disruption but seldom keep the momentum going to create businesses that eventually turn cash positive. Most factots point towards a volatile ecosystem that could swing either way. Disruption, innovation, IoT, AI, ML and a few other dangerous sounding words will continue to rule the roost the coming years. All this sounds glum. And it is. A deep dive into the sinister world of startups will reveal a lot more. But yeah! To answer your question, startups do contribute to the economy. Cheers

Startups helps in increasing the economic activity levels of a nation which is necessary for expansion of the economy to accommodate new job seekers that come into the civilian labor force on an yearly basis. It helps in improving the technology advantage of a nation for future development and growth of the economy. It improves the wealth levels of a nation and revenue streams for the government to initiate its welfare and other citizen endowment programs. Without innovation a capitalists system will degenerate, so startups helps in building good and efficient r&d, which is necessary in this direction of political philosophy of wealth creation. More startups keep the economy healthy.
